The ostlers told me that the house belonged to a gentleman of the name of Dr. Roylott, a man of great wealth and repute, who lived there with his wife and daughter. They also told me that the family was in the habit of spending the summer months in the country, and that they had only just arrived. I thanked the ostlers for their information, and, feeling that I had done a good morning's work, I returned to the village, where I found my friend the constable, who was much pleased with my report. I then took my leave of him, and returned to my lodgings, where I spent the rest of the day in writing up my journal, and in making arrangements for my departure on the following morning. As I was sitting at my desk, I heard a knock at the door, and, on opening it, I found a servant, who handed me a note, which proved to be an invitation from Dr. Roylott to dine with him and his family on the following day. I was much surprised at this, as I had not expected that my visit would have become known to the family, and I was not a little pleased at the prospect of making their acquaintance. I accordingly accepted the invitation, and the servant, who was waiting for an answer, departed. I then returned to my desk, and, feeling that I had a good deal to think about, I spent the rest of the evening in considering the events of the day, and in wondering what the morrow might bring.

The ceremony was already underway, and I slipped quietly into a pew at the back of the church, trying not to draw attention to myself. The woman, dressed in a simple yet elegant white gown, was repeating her vows, her voice trembling slightly as she spoke. The man, tall and dark-haired, stood beside her, his eyes fixed adoringly on her face. I watched, fascinated, as they exchanged rings and sealed their union with a kiss. As they turned to face the congregation, the clergyman smiled and pronounced them husband and wife. The couple beamed at each other, and I couldn't help but feel a pang of envy at their happiness. I had never been one for grand romantic gestures, but there was something about this moment that touched my heart. As the newlyweds made their way back down the aisle, I rose to my feet, along with the others, and applauded politely. The couple emerged from the church, blinking in the bright sunlight, and made their way to the waiting carriage. I watched as they drove away, feeling a sense of nostalgia wash over me. I had never been much of a romantic, but this wedding had stirred something deep within me. I turned to make my way back to my own carriage, lost in thought, when I heard a voice behind me. "Excuse me, sir," it said. I turned to see a young woman, dressed in a simple yet elegant gown, smiling up at me. "I couldn't help but notice you were at the wedding," she said. "Were you a friend of the groom?" I hesitated for a moment, unsure of how to respond. I had been so caught up in the moment, I hadn't thought about how I would explain my presence. "I...I was just a passerby," I stammered. The woman's eyes sparkled with amusement. "A passerby who just happened to arrive at the church at the exact moment the ceremony was starting?" she asked, raising an eyebrow. I felt a flush rise to my cheeks as I realized I had been caught out. "I...I suppose I was curious," I admitted, feeling a bit sheepish. The woman laughed, a musical sound. "I think you were more than just curious," she said, her eyes glinting with amusement. "But I suppose that's a story for another time." And with that, she turned and disappeared into the crowd, leaving me feeling both intrigued and perplexed.

La palabra no había salido de mi boca cuando toda la multitud de espectadores, tanto los bien vestidos como los mal vestidos, caballeros, posaderos y sirvientas, se unieron en un grito general de "¡Fuego!". Gruesas nubes de humo se extendieron por la habitación

Deslizándome entre la multitud que gritaba, me dirigí a la esquina de la calle, y en diez minutos me alegré de encontrar el brazo de mi amigo entre los míos, y de alejarme de la escena del alboroto. Caminó con rapidez y en silencio durante algunos minutos hasta que doblamos por una de las tranquilas calles que conducen a Edgeware Road.

es_results_raw: resolver el misterio de la desaparición de su hermano, era necesario que el señor Sherlock Holmes y yo nos trasladáramos a la casa de campo de la familia, situada en el condado de Sussex. Aunque parecía un caso sencillo, pronto nos dimos cuenta de que había algo más detrás de la desaparición de la joven. La señorita Mary nos había dicho que su hermano había salido de casa para ir a dar un paseo por el bosque, pero no había regresado. La familia estaba muy preocupada, ya que el joven no había llevado dinero ni comida, y no había dejado ninguna nota que indicara adónde iba. El señor Holmes y yo decidimos que era necesario investigar más a fondo y, tras hablar con la familia y los sirvientes, nos dirigimos al bosque para buscar pistas. Al llegar allí, nos encontramos con un paisaje desolado y silencioso, con árboles secos y un suelo cubierto de hojas. El señor Holmes se puso a examinar el terreno con su lupa, buscando cualquier señal que pudiera indicarnos el paradero del joven desaparecido. De repente, se detuvo y se agachó para examinar algo más de cerca. "¿Qué es, Holmes?", le pregunté. "Un trozo de tela", me respondió. "Parece ser de la ropa del joven. Creo que estamos en el camino correcto".

I have been summoned to see Lord Harrington, and I wish you to be present as my secretary.' I was so taken aback that I could hardly believe my ears. I had never been inside the Foreign Office, and the thought of being summoned there, even in so subordinate a capacity, was almost overwhelming. I felt as though I was walking on air as I followed Mr. Holmes to the great building in Downing Street. We were shown at once into the waiting-room, where several other people were already assembled. I recognized the Duke of Norfolk and Lord Rosebery, and wondered what could be the meaning of this gathering. After a few minutes we were shown into the great room where the Minister was seated at his desk. He was a tall, thin man with a very stern expression, and he looked at us over the top of his glasses as we entered. 'Ah, Mr. Holmes,' he said, 'I am glad you have come. I have a very important matter to discuss with you.' He motioned to a chair, and Mr. Holmes sat down. I remained standing, feeling a little awkward, until he said, 'And this is your secretary, I presume?' 'Yes, my lord,' said Mr. Holmes. 'Mr. ——' 'Harrington,' I said, trying to speak calmly. The Minister nodded, and began to explain the reason for our summons.

Yo, por mi parte, me mantuve atento al camino, observando el paisaje que desfilaba ante mis ojos, pero sin poder evitar que mi mente volviera una y otra vez a la misteriosa figura de Sherlock Holmes, que parecía estar sumido en un mundo propio, ajeno a todo lo que le rodeaba. El taxi avanzaba lentamente, y el silencio era solo roto por el sonido de las ruedas sobre el pavimento y el ocasional claxon de un coche que pasaba por nuestro lado. De repente, el taxi se detuvo, y el conductor se volvió hacia nosotros y dijo: "Llegamos, caballeros". Holmes se incorporó de inmediato, y miró a su alrededor, como si estuviera despertando de un sueño. "¿Dónde estamos?", preguntó. "En la estación de tren", respondió el conductor. "¿Y cuánto nos queda para llegar a nuestro destino?", inquirió Holmes. "Unos 20 minutos", dijo el conductor. Holmes asintió con la cabeza, y se apeó del taxi, seguido de mí. Mientras pagábamos al conductor, Holmes miró a su alrededor, y de repente, se dirigió hacia la estación, con paso rápido y decidido. Yo le seguí, sin saber qué nos esperaba en nuestro destino, pero con la certeza de que con Sherlock Holmes, siempre había algo interesante y misterioso en el aire.

I waited with bated breath, my eyes straining to pierce the darkness, but it was impossible to see anything. The silence was oppressive, and I could feel the weight of the darkness pressing down upon me. Suddenly, I heard a faint noise, a slight rustling sound, and I knew that whatever was making it was moving slowly and cautiously. I tightened my grip on the revolver, my finger on the trigger, ready to fire at the slightest movement. The sound grew louder, and I could tell that it was coming from the far corner of the room. I held my breath, waiting for whatever it was to make its next move. And then, just as suddenly as it had started, the noise stopped. "How did you know?" he asked, his voice barely above a whisper. "I know many things, Mr. Hatherley," replied Holmes, with a slight smile. "But I must confess, I am curious. "I fear for my life," he said, his voice firm. "I fear that I am in grave danger." Holmes's eyes narrowed. "And what makes you think this, Mr. Hatherley?" he asked, his voice sharp with interest. "I have received a threatening letter," replied the man. "A letter that tells me that I will be killed if I do not do as I am told." Holmes's eyes gleamed with excitement. en_first_half: “The man married a woman very much older than himself for her money,” said he, “and he enjoyed the use of the money of the daughter as long as she lived with them. It was a considerable sum, for people in their position, and the loss of it would have made a serious difference. It was worth an effort to preserve it. The daughter was of a good, amiable disposition, but affectionate and warm-hearted in her ways, so that it was evident that with her fair personal advantages, and her little income, she would not be allowed to remain single long. Now her marriage would mean, of course, the loss of a hundred a year, so what does her stepfather do to prevent it? He takes the obvious course
en_second_half: of keeping her at home and forbidding her to seek the company of people of her own age. But soon he found that that would not answer forever. She became restive, insisted upon her rights, and finally announced her positive intention of going to a certain ball. What does her clever stepfather do then? He conceives an idea more creditable to his head than to his heart. With the connivance and assistance of his wife he disguised himself, covered those keen eyes with tinted glasses, masked the face with a moustache and a pair of bushy whiskers, sunk that clear voice into an insinuating whisper, and doubly secure on account of the girl’s short sight, he appears as Mr. Hosmer Angel, and keeps off other lovers by making love himself.”

But I, who knew the man and knew the ways of the place, I had no doubt in my mind from the first that it was a case of foul play. I had, however, no more to go upon than a vague suspicion, and McFarlane, the constable, was quite clear that there was no case against the man who was known to have been the last with the deceased. That man's name was William Higgins, a fisherman of the village, and he and the deceased had been seen together in the village inn, the "Lion's Head," that night. I had, however, a certain knowledge of the man, Higgins, which I did not share with the constable. I knew that he was a man of a violent temper, and that there had been a long-standing feud between him and the deceased, concerning some right of way, or so, in the fishing grounds. I had, too, a certain suspicion that Higgins was not the kind of man to be trifled with, and that if he had a grudge against a man, he would stick at nothing to satisfy it. I was, therefore, not surprised when, a few days after the inquest, Higgins came to me and asked to speak with me in private. I took him to my study, and he began by saying that he had heard that I had been making inquiries about the death of the deceased, and that he wished to know what I was driving at. I told him that I had simply been trying to get at the truth of the matter, and that I had no particular object in view. He seemed to accept this, and then went on to say that he had something to tell me, which he thought I ought to know. He said that on the night of the deceased's death, he had been in the village inn, the "Lion's Head," and that the deceased had come in, the worse for drink. He said that they had had some words, but that nothing serious had come of it, and that the deceased had left the inn, and he had not seen him again. He said, too, that he had not left the inn himself until it was closing time, and that he had gone straight home, and had not been out again that night. I listened to what he had to say, and I could see that he was speaking the truth, or, at least, what he believed to be the truth. But I could not help feeling that there was something behind, something that he was not telling me, and I determined to keep a close eye on him, and to see if I could not find out what it was. And that, Mr. Holmes, is as far as I have got in the matter. I have told you all that I know, and I hope that you may be able to throw some light upon it.

Bạn có thể cho tôi biết cái ao này có sâu bao nhiêu không?" Tôi trả lời: "Chỉ sâu có hơn hai foot." Ông Holmes gật đầu và nói: "Tôi đã hiểu. Tôi sẽ giải thích cho bạn biết vụ việc này sau." Ông Holmes bắt đầu giải thích: "Bác bạn của bạn đã chết vì một lý do rất đơn giản. Bác đã chết vì ngạt nước. Nhưng không phải do tự tử, mà là do một sự cố ý. Ai đó đã đẩy bác vào ao và khiến bác chết." Tôi nghe ông Holmes nói và cảm thấy sốc. "Ai đó? Ai có thể làm điều đó?" Tôi hỏi. Ông Holmes mỉm cười và nói: "Tôi sẽ tìm ra người đó. Nhưng trước tiên, bạn cần phải giúp tôi tìm hiểu thêm về hoàn cảnh và tính cách của bác bạn." Tôi gật đầu và sẵn sàng giúp đỡ ông Holmes. Chúng tôi bắt đầu điều tra và sau một thời gian, chúng tôi đã tìm ra người đã giết bác tôi. Đó là một người đàn ông trẻ, người đã từng làm việc cho bác tôi. Người đó đã giết bác tôi vì một lý do rất đơn giản: tiền bạc. Bác tôi đã để lại một số tiền lớn cho người đó, nhưng người đó đã không hài lòng và muốn có thêm. Vì vậy, người đó đã giết bác tôi và cố ý làm cho mọi người nghĩ rằng đó là một vụ tự tử. Nhưng nhờ sự giúp đỡ của ông Holmes, chúng tôi đã tìm ra sự thật và người đó đã bị bắt giữ. "Đó là dấu vết của một loại thuốc," Holmes trả lời, "và nó sẽ giúp chúng ta biết được tên tội phạm đã sử dụng loại thuốc gì để giết người." en_first_half: “Away we went then, and we drove for at least an hour. Colonel Lysander Stark had said that it was only seven miles, but I should think, from the rate that we seemed to go, and from the time that we took, that it must have been nearer twelve. He sat at my side in silence all the time, and I was aware, more than once when I glanced in his direction, that he was looking at me with great intensity. The country roads seem to be not very good in that part of the world, for we lurched and jolted terribly. I tried to look out of the windows to see something of where we were, but they were made of frosted glass, and I could make out nothing save the occasional bright blur
en_second_half: of a passing light. Now and then I hazarded some remark to break the monotony of the journey, but the colonel answered only in monosyllables, and the conversation soon flagged. At last, however, the bumping of the road was exchanged for the crisp smoothness of a gravel-drive, and the carriage came to a stand. Colonel Lysander Stark sprang out, and, as I followed after him, pulled me swiftly into a porch which gaped in front of us. We stepped, as it were, right out of the carriage and into the hall, so that I failed to catch the most fleeting glance of the front of the house. The instant that I had crossed the threshold the door slammed heavily behind us, and I heard faintly the rattle of the wheels as the carriage drove away.
en_results: of a street lamp or the gleam of a white wall. The Colonel's silence began to make me feel uneasy, and I found myself wondering what I had done to offend him. I tried to think of something to say, but my mind seemed to have gone completely blank. I was relieved when at last the car stopped in front of a large, old-fashioned house, and the Colonel turned to me and said, "We have arrived." I got out of the car and looked around, but there was nothing to see. The house stood alone, surrounded by trees, and the only sound was the distant hooting of an owl. The Colonel took my arm and led me towards the house, and I could feel his eyes on me again. I began to feel a sense of foreboding, and I wondered what lay ahead. As we reached
en_results_raw: of a street lamp or the gleam of a white wall. The Colonel's silence began to make me feel uneasy, and I found myself wondering what I had done to offend him. I tried to think of something to say, but my mind seemed to have gone completely blank. I was relieved when at last the car stopped in front of a large, old-fashioned house, and the Colonel turned to me and said, "We have arrived." I got out of the car and looked around, but there was nothing to see. The house stood alone, surrounded by trees, and the only sound was the distant hooting of an owl. The Colonel took my arm and led me towards the house, and I could feel his eyes on me again. I began to feel a sense of foreboding, and I wondered what lay ahead. As we reached the door, it was opened by a tall, thin man with a gaunt face, who bowed low and said, "Welcome, Colonel. I see you have brought your guest." The Colonel nodded, and the man stepped aside to let us pass. I found myself in a long, dark hallway, with doors leading off to either side. The Colonel led me to a door at the far end, which he opened and motioned me to enter. I did so, and found myself in a large, dimly lit room, with a fire burning in the grate. The Colonel followed me in, and closed the door behind us. I turned to him, and said, "Where are we? What is this place?" He looked at me, and I saw something in his eyes that made my blood run cold. "You will know soon enough," he said. "But first, you must see something. Come." He turned and walked across the room, and I followed him, my heart pounding in my chest. We reached a door on the far side of the room, and the Colonel opened it and motioned me to enter. I did so, and found myself in a small, dimly lit room, with a single chair in the center. And in that chair, bound and gagged, was a woman. I gasped, and the Colonel's voice came from behind me. "You see, my dear, this is why I brought you here. This is the woman you have been searching for." I spun round, but the Colonel was not there. And then I heard his voice again, from the other side of the room. "But you are not going to save her. You are going to join her." And as I turned to face him, I saw that he was holding a gun. I tried to run, but my feet seemed rooted to the spot. And then everything went black.

Tôi ngồi vào cái ghế còn lại và nhìn ông ta. "Chúng ta sẽ nói về cái gì?", tôi hỏi. "Chúng ta sẽ nói về việc của anh", ông ta trả lời. "Việc của tôi?", tôi hỏi lại. "Vâng, việc của anh", ông ta nói. "Anh là một người rất đặc biệt", ông ta tiếp tục. "Anh có một khả năng rất đặc biệt". "Khả năng gì?", tôi hỏi. "Anh có khả năng nhìn thấu vào tương lai", ông ta nói. "Tương lai?", tôi hỏi lại. "Vâng, tương lai", ông ta trả lời. "Anh có thể nhìn thấy những gì sẽ xảy ra trong tương lai", ông ta tiếp tục. "Vậy thì tại sao anh lại nói với tôi những điều này?", tôi hỏi. "Bởi vì anh cần phải biết", ông ta nói. "Biết để làm gì?", tôi hỏi lại. "Để anh có thể chuẩn bị", ông ta trả lời. "Chuẩn bị cho gì?", tôi hỏi. "Chuẩn bị cho tương lai", ông ta nói. "Tương lai sẽ là như thế nào?", tôi hỏi. "Tương lai sẽ là một nơi rất khác", ông ta trả lời. "Khác như thế nào?", tôi hỏi lại. "Khác hoàn toàn", ông ta nói. es_first_half: "Nos fuimos entonces, y condujimos durante al menos una hora. El coronel Lysander Stark había dicho que sólo eran siete millas, pero yo creía, por la velocidad a la que parecíamos ir, y por el tiempo que tardamos, que debían ser más de doce. Se sentó a mi lado en silencio todo el tiempo, y me di cuenta, más de una vez cuando miré en su dirección, que me estaba mirando con gran intensidad. Parece que las carreteras rurales no son muy buenas en esa parte del mundo, porque dimos unos bandazos y sacudidas terribles. Intenté mirar por las ventanillas para ver algo de dónde estábamos, pero eran de vidrio esmerilado, y no pude distinguir nada más que el borrón ocasional de una luz que pasaba. De vez en
es_second_half: cuando me arriesgaba a hacer algún comentario para romper la monotonía del viaje, pero el coronel sólo respondía con monosílabos, y la conversación pronto decaía. Por fin, sin embargo, los golpes de la carretera fueron sustituidos por la crujiente suavidad de un camino de grava, y el carruaje se detuvo. El coronel Lysander Stark se bajó de él y, mientras yo lo seguía, me arrastró a un porche que se abría ante nosotros. Bajamos, por así decirlo, del carruaje y entramos en el vestíbulo, de modo que no pude echar la más fugaz mirada a la fachada de la casa. En el instante en que crucé el umbral, la puerta se cerró de golpe detrás de nosotros, y oí débilmente el traqueteo de las ruedas mientras el carruaje se alejaba."

Me encontré en un lugar desconocido, rodeado de edificios altos y oscuros que parecían cerrados y abandonados. El coronel Stark me tomó del brazo y me llevó hacia uno de los edificios, sin decir una palabra. Me sentía confundido y un poco asustado, pero no podía hacer nada más que seguirlo. ¿Qué era lo que íbamos a hacer allí? ¿Qué era lo que el coronel Stark quería mostrarme? No tenia ni idea, pero estaba a punto de descubrirlo.

en_first_half: “That is well. The letter which I hold in my hand is from Lord St. Simon. I will read it to you,
en_second_half: and in return you must turn over these papers and let me have whatever bears upon the matter. This is what he says:
en_results: My dear fellow,” it runs, “I hope this letter finds you in good health and high spirits. I am writing to you from the
en_results_raw: “My dear fellow,” it runs, “I hope this letter finds you in good health and high spirits. I am writing to you from the country, where I have been spending a few days in the hope of recruiting my strength, which, as you know, has been failing me of late. But though the change of air has done me some good, I am still far from well, and I fear that I shall never again be the man I once was. I am writing to you now, however, not to speak of my own health, but to tell you of something which I think will interest you. You know how anxious I have been to see the matter of the will settled, and I am happy to be able to tell you that it is now almost done. The lawyers have been at work upon it for some time, and they tell me that it will be ready for signature in a few days. I am glad of this, for I am anxious to have the thing finished, and to know that all is secure for the future. I hope, my dear fellow, that you will be pleased at this news, and that you will come to me as soon as the will is signed, that we may talk over the matter, and make our arrangements for the future. I am, my dear fellow, yours faithfully, St. Simon.”
